--- title: "MT Post Farm Analysis Report" author: "Jackson Strand" date: "2024-03-20" output: html_document: theme: cosmo toc: true toc_float: true toc_title: "Table of Contents" toc_collapsed: false toc_depth: 4 # number_sections: true editor_options: chunk_output_type: console toc: true --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ```{=html} Image Cropping Example
``` # POST FARM ## Methods ### Plant Selection and Cages Assessment of C. cinctus infestation and mortality within B. inermis were assessed using a 34 x 60 ft plot at the Arthur H. Post Agronomy Farm (43°38'19.39"N, 116°14'28.86"W), an extension research station of Montana State University in Bozeman, MT. The cage structure was built using 1-inch PVC piping with the netting made using 530\(\mu\) Amber Lumite Screen (BioQuip® Products, LLC). Twelve cages were built to dimensions of 6ft x 3ft x 3ft (L x W x H) with cage locations selected randomly based on the space available within the plot and arranged in sets of three. The cages were removed from the plot after 3 weeks of sawfly release. ### Insects Wheat stem stubble was collected in Three Forks, MT, USA (43°38'19.39"N, 116°14'28.86"W) from fields that experienced high levels of C. cinctus infestation and cutting in the prior year. Cut stubble, which contained C. cinctus larvae in diapause, were kept refrigerated between -2°C and 3°C for >100 days as required to complete obligatory larval diapause. As needed, stubs were removed from refrigeration and kept at 22-27°C for 4-5 weeks inside of 100 oz GladWare® storage containers (Glad®, Oakland, California USA). Stubs were added to cages once B. inermis stems reached six inches tall, with sawfly quantity treatments as follows: high (600 stubs), low (200 stubs), and control (0 stubs). #### Data Collection Stems were collected from each cage site in late August. All stems from each 6 x 3 ft cage section were collected. Each stem was sliced open using X-Acto® knives to collect data on infestation, dead larvae, live larvae, and parasitism at each internode. ## Analysis ### Overall WSS Infestation and Cutting ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: #### Basic Table and Plot of Infestation
2023 Post Farm Infestation
Treatment Total Stems % Inf % Cut
control 337 0.00 0.00
high 421 0.71 0.13
low 415 0.51 0.03
2022 Post Farm Infestation
Treatment Total Stems % Inf % Cut
control 444 0.00 0.00
high 418 0.65 0.03
low 387 0.45 0.02
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](pfreport_files/figure-html/post farm plot-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: Let's take a closer look at the number of nodes borrowed through by the larvae. Using this information we can make an arguement about the size and length of time each larvae was alive prior to dying. This can be informative in understanding how many larvae would have been left later in the season for potential parasitism. #### Infestation Percentage/Node ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](pfreport_files/figure-html/v.r infestation node-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
ANOVA Table
Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F-Value Pr(>F)
treatment 1 0.044 0.044 6.692 0.0144
nodes.inf 5 0.286 0.057 8.612 0.0000
v.r 2 0.057 0.029 4.303 0.0221
Residuals 32 0.213 0.007 NA NA
````` ::: ::: Based on the results of our ANOVA, we have weak evidence (Pval = 0.0221) to suggest there is a difference in the number of nodes infested when considering treatment group and vegetative and reproductive stems. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Cumulative sum of nodes infested
# of Nodes Infested
Treatment 6 5 4 3 2 1
high 0.01 0.13 0.36 0.69 0.89 1
low 0.03 0.13 0.47 0.76 0.94 1
````` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](pfreport_files/figure-html/cumsum of infestation per node-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: I like this plot because it shows the cumulative percentage sum of nodes infested at each node. For example, at the 3rd node in 2023, we see that close to 70% of the stems in the 'high' treatment group exhibited between 3 and 6 nodes infested. As a general thought exercise, the more nodes a larvae burrowed through, the larger the larvae. This means that if we classify a "large" larvae as one who burrowed through at least 4 nodes, our infestation data shows that 36% of the larvae in the 'high' treatment groups died as "large" larvae. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Stems with Living Larvae (2023)
Treatment Count Total Stems %
high 26 421 0.062
low 35 415 0.084
````` ::: ::: Interesting to see that 6.2% of stems in the 'high' treatment groups and 8.4% of stems in the 'low' treatment group had living WSS larvae. The stems for this experiement were harvested in late October, much later in the season when we would expect the second generation parasitoids to be searching for a host.
